Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2009 07:02PM NeoPat wrote: I had a unilateral mastectomy in April 2007.  There was really no choice because I had multiple tumors. I never even considered a bilateral at the time.  Now I am most likely about to have the second breast removed because of LIN (a type of precancerous cells that tend to be multifocal). I had an excisional biopsy about a year ago and need another one now. I think that I will just have another mastectomy and be done with it. Although, I might be about to go through surgery and recovery again, I am not sorry that I didn't do it back then.  I was just not emotionally ready and I might have always wondered if it was necessary.  Now I feel like it is probably my best choice. I have an appointment with my surgeon tomorrow and will make my decision after I talk with her. Good luck. Pat

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2009 03:36PM NeoPat wrote: First of all, you are not a whiner.  I can't answer your questions in any detail, but I would not go through with any procedures that I had so many questions about.  Do you have the option of getting a second opinion? Pat
Posts.Title: duct excision/ductogram cosmetic concerns sameasalways djmammo

Posts.Content: May 14, 2009 02:28PM NeoPat wrote: A medical person that I know told me that there is something that they can insert in the incision area that is like novacaine.  I think that it "disolves" over a few days.  She said that it works very well and is not a narcotic. Sorry that I can't describe it any better, but perhaps something to look into. In defence of people who do have a lot of pain after a mastectomy, let me say that I have had two of them at separate times and one hurt a lot and the other hardly at all. No recon either time. I think the difference in my case is that the first time I had pretty extensive cancer and the surgeon removed the lining of the chest wall muscles.  The second time (a week ago) was preventive and she did not do that. Pat

Posts.Title: Core Biopsy - some advice worried_husband NeoPat

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2009 06:11AM NeoPat wrote: I had an MRI that showed a small lesion, which did not show on ultrasound or mammogram.  I knew that it could be a false positive, but decided to go with the MRI-guided biopsy.  That turned up LIN (lobular intraepithelial neoplsia).  I think that LIN is a term used to include everything from ALH to LCIS.  An excisional bx would be the next step. I had an excisional bx in a different area of the same breast a year ago after a core needle bx found ADH.  The excisional bx found LIN. I've decided to get a mastectomy and end all the testing and waiting for results.  I already had one mast. two years ago for multifocal IDC. MRIs are more sensitive and can find things that are not seen on u/s, so I wouldn't automatically blame it on the technician. Pat
